metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1953 and Civil Appeal No. 12 of 1954

facts.text: Appellant contractor entered into contract with Dominion of India through Additional Chief Engineer of C.P.W.D. on 1-11-1945 for supply of 2-1/2 crores of pucca bricks to be delivered at kiln site according to schedule: 30 lacs by 25-1-46, 50 lacs by 25-2-46, 55 lacs by 25-3-46, 55 lacs by 25-4-46, 60 lacs by 25-5-46.
Disputes arose; clause 14 provided all disputes to be referred to Superintending Engineer of the Circle.
Reference to arbitration on 21-1-1949; award given on 8-5-1949 filed in Court of Subordinate Judge, Dhanbad.
Contractor prayed for decree in terms of award; Union of India (replacing Dominion) filed objections under s.30 Arbitration Act, prayed award be set aside or modified.
Contractor's application registered as suit under s.20 Arbitration Act; decree passed in terms of award on 18-3-1950.
Union of India appealed to High Court of Patna; appeal allowed in part on 11-5-1951.
Contractor had to prepare katcha bricks in advance; C.P.W.D. failed to remove baked bricks promptly, causing jam and accumulation of 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed by rain.
Additional clause 6: 'The department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.'
Claim 5: Rs.75,900 for 88 lacs katcha bricks destroyed by rain; arbitrator awarded Rs.64,075 holding clause 6 not absolving department from contractual obligations.
Claim 8: Rs.51,495 for additional wages due to non-supply of ration and cloth; rationing in Sindri area, contractor employed 1800 coolies from far off, department promised supply.
Contractor tender 25-9-45, accepted 1-11-45, warned Executive Engineer 9-11-45, contract signed 22-11-45 without ration clause.
Arbitrator awarded Rs.40,000 on claim 8 holding implied contractual obligation for controlled rations.
Claim 17: Interest Rs.27,665 at 6% for 16 months from 1-1-48; work finished May 1946.
Arbitrator awarded interest on awarded amounts holding claims should have been settled by Jan 1948.
In CA 12/1954: Similar contract 1-11-1945 same terms; award 1-5-1949; disputes on claims 4 (rations/cloth Rs.51,495, awarded Rs.30,000) and 17 (interest Rs.27,665, awarded Rs.9,954).
No specific question of law referred to arbitrator; disputes from contractor's letters and petition Ex.B1.
Contractor awarded under other claims: Rs.11,744-11-0 (claim 4 extra loading), Rs.15,500 (claim 13 levelling land).

legal_issues.text: Whether arbitrator erred in law on face of award by awarding on claim 5 ignoring clause 6, as no specific question of law referred.
Whether arbitrator erred in law by finding implied contractual obligation for rations/cloth supply on claim 8/4.
Whether arbitrator had power to award interest on unliquidated claims under claim 17.
Scope of court interference under s.16(1)(c) Arbitration Act when error of law apparent on face of award, absent specific reference of question of law.

petitioner_arguments.text: Loss of katcha bricks due to department's failure to lift quota; clause 6 not applicable as department at fault and refers to damage not destruction.
Department promised ration supply pre-contract; circumstantial evidence shows mutual understanding; moral and legal liability.
Interest due as claims should have been settled by 31-12-1947; blocked funds forced borrowing.

respondent_arguments.text: Katcha bricks not part of contract; loss remote; clause 6 expressly excludes liability for damage to unburnt bricks.
No promise or clause for rations; contract signed without it; government bound only by signed contracts.
No basis for interest on unliquidated claims.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 6 expressly excludes liability for damage to unburnt bricks; arbitrator wrong in construing it not to absolve department from contractual duties; error apparent on face as no specific law question referred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parties expressly agreed no liability for such remote loss.

court_reasoning.text: No implied contract for rations; contractor signed without waiting for reply; one-sided contention not evidence; rationing provincial matter, not Dominion's control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts cannot be found from mere contention denied by other side.

court_reasoning.text: No power to award interest on unliquidated sums; Interest Act conditions not met; arbitrator not court under CPC s.34.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Debt must be certain, payable by written contract at certain time with demand.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.16(1)(c) Arbitration Act, court can remit if legal error on face; no interference if specific law question referred, but here only incidental; requires both parties' assent or court order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arbitrator bound by law unless specific reference.

holdings.text: Clause 6 relieves government of liability for katcha bricks damage; arbitrator erred in law.
No implied or collateral contract for rations/cloth; falls outside arbitration clause.
Arbitrator has no power to award interest on unliquidated claims.
Courts can correct arbitrator's legal errors apparent on face unless specific question of law referred by both parties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kelantan Government v. Duff Development Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Specific reference of law question needed for finality.

precedents_cited.case_name: F. R. Absalom Ltd. v. Great Western London Garden Village Society
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles on court interference when no specific law reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Champsey Bhara Co. v. Jivraj Balloo Spinning and Weaving Co.
A. M. Mair Co. v. Gordhandass Sagarmull
precedents_cited.relevance: Dispute must be defined and referred.
Arbitration clause confined to referred matters.
Wider language confined to specific facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Nagpur Ry. Co. v. Ruttanji Ramji
precedents_cited.relevance: Interest not payable by law on unliquidated sums.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Objections to award; filing award; remit for legal error on face.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Interest post-suit; not applicable to arbitrators.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed contractor's appeals, upholding High Court's partial allowance of government's appeal by setting aside arbitrator's awards on disputed claims 5,8,17 (CA 260/1953) and 4,17 (CA 12/1954) due to errors of law apparent on face of award.
outcome.relief_granted: None to contractor; awards on disputed items set aside.

key_quotes.text: An arbitrator is not a conciliator and cannot ignore the law or misapply it in order to do what he thinks is just and reasonable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines arbitrator's duty to follow law.

key_quotes.text: The department will not entertain any claim for idle labour or for damage to unburnt bricks due to any cause whatsoever.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: If a question of law is specifically referred... the Courts will not interfere.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits court non-interference to specific references.
